div1.head: Military Orders for Jefferson Randolph Kean, C. B. Hepburn, and E. A. Teeter, July 3, 1900 [selected page]
div1.p:
Adjutant General's
OFFICE,
JUL 24 1900
ROLLS DIVISION
[unclear]

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 179 B 1900

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF HAVANA
AND PINAR DEL RIO.

1. Leave of absence for one (1) month is hereby granted
Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. Volunteers.

With the approval of the Division Commander, permis-
sion is granted to go beyond the limits of the Division.

2. Leave of absence for one (1) month, on surgeon's cer-
tificate of disability, is hereby granted Captain C. B.
Hepburn, Signal Officer, U. S. Volunteers.

With the approval of the Division Commander, permis-
sion is granted to go beyond the limits of the Division.

3. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Surgeon,
Hospital Steward Clark L. Brown, U. S. Army, is hereby
assigned to temporary duty at these headquarters in the
office of the Chief Surgeon.

4. Upon the recommendation of the Acting Chief Surgeon,
Private E. Albert Teeter, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army, is here-
by relieved from duty at these headquarters and assigned
to Columbia Barracks, and will report accordingly.

5. Private Albin Seifert, Company K, 1st Infantry, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Guanajay
Barracks, Cuba, charged with suffering prisoners to escape,
to the prejudice of good order and military discipline, in
violation of the 62d Article of War, was acquitted.

The acquittal is approved. Private Seifert has already
been ordered released from arrest and restored to duty.

6. Private John Dixon, Troop A, 7th Cavalry, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Columbia
Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of conduct to the pre-
judice of good order and military discipline, in violation of
the 62d Article of War (one previous conviction), was sen-
tenced “To be confined at hard labor, under charge of the post
guard, for three (3) months.”
The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed.

7. Private James B. Coulter, Company G, 8th Infantry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, charged with disobedience of
orders, in violation of the 21st Article of War, was
acquitted.
